node.title: Briscoe Group sales remain stable despite lockdowns
node.description: Briscoe Group says third quarter sales have delivered a solid result, despite the impact of ongoing lockdowns.

node.title: KiwiSaver third quarter returns relatively unaffected by lockdowns
node.description: KiwiSaver funds reflected subdued market conditions over the September quarter, with the bulk experiencing a return of less than one percent.

node.title: No, Kroger isn't accepting bitcoin as payment at its stores
node.description: News release posted on grocery chain's site claimed it now accepts Bitcoin Cash, but company says announcement is fake.

node.title: Cuomo arraignment delayed after DA rips "troubling" handling of case
node.description: Cuomo has denied the claim made in the complaint.

node.title: What to Do This Weekend
node.description: Change your clocks, contemplate your dreams.

node.title: Defense lawyers portray the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery as self-defense.
node.description: The lawyers represent Travis McMichael, who fatally shot Mr. Arbery, and his father. The lawyer for the third defendant deferred his opening statement until later in the trial.

node.title: Meet the Indigenous artist who helped design the 2023 Women's World Cup branding
node.description: Chern'ee Sutton, a Kalkadoon artist from Queensland, has designed the NRL's Indigenous All-Stars jersey, tennis trophies, and the 2018 Commonwealth Games mascot. Now, she's created art for one of football's biggest tournaments: the Women's World Cup.

node.title: Bones in the Backyard: How Police Cracked a Grisly Cold Case
node.description: George Seitz’s disappearance in 1976 drew little notice — until investigators found his skeleton in a backyard more than 40 years later.

node.title: Internet Slams Bride's Expensive 'Requests' After Bridesmaids 'Step Down' Due to Cost
node.description: "You have no right to spend other [folks'] money so freely. Friends don't put friends into debt," wrote one commenter on the bride's pricy demands.

node.title: Colin Powell Once Serenaded Foreign Official With Abba Song, Friend Recalls at Funeral
node.description: The longtime military man and civil servant had a well-known personal obsession with the Swedish pop band, one that was remembered at his funeral.

node.title: Net run rate to give cricket fans sore heads tonight, but a better tie breaker may be just over the rope
node.description: It may determine the T20 World Cup semi-finalists tonight, but fans can be forgiven for asking: How does net run rate work again?

node.title: China's COVID death rate is curiously low. An anonymous Beijing doctor told us how they’re doing it
node.description: Official figures suggest China may have become a global leader in keeping COVID-19 patients alive. But can the numbers be believed?

node.title: Detectives piece together Cleo abduction: 'There's a huge investigation going on'
node.description: Collecting evidence to show four-year-old Cleo Smith was held against her will in a Carnarvon home is only part of the ongoing work for police investigators.

node.title: U.N. hunger agency chief issues plea to billionaires
node.description: "The number of people knocking on famine's door now is unprecedented," said David Beasley.

node.title: China Supports Syria's Reconstruction, Security Cooperation in Call Between Xi, Assad
node.description: President Xi said China "supports the struggle of the Syrians in defending the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of their country."

node.title: Aaron Rodgers Calls Vaccinations Too Political, Stances Changed When Biden Entered Office
node.description: "Health should not be political," Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers said during an interview on Friday.

node.title: New York City Marathon Set to Return With a Variety of Pandemic-Forced Changes
node.description: The 33,000 runners are expected to be vaccinated or show proof of a negative COVID-19 test within 48 hours.

node.title: Black Ferns deserve respect and scrutiny, instead of being patronised
node.description: Opinion - The Black Ferns were on a hiding to nothing against England. In the aftermath of that defeat there's been no examination of what went wrong, writes [Hamish Bidwell].

node.title: 'Oratory can affect the course of history': What Shakespeare's words have taught John Bell over the years
node.description: Shakespeare's work has become a secular Bible for actor and director John Bell. Over the past 60 years, it's taught him about empathy, ambition, leadership and the power of language.

node.title: 'Wellness warriors' and misinformation blamed for vaccine lag in wealthy suburbs
node.description: Some of Melbourne's richest areas are among the least vaccinated in Victoria, figures show, with the trend leaving local doctors concerned about what is to come.

node.title: Lockdowns have ended in Sydney and Melbourne so why are many businesses still struggling?
node.description: The scarcity of international students has a significant impact on hospitality and other industries in Australia, with some forced to reduce operating hours while others struggle with understaffing.

node.title: It's a 'priority' technology in Australia's net zero plan. Critics say it's a 'scam'
node.description: Part of Australia's net zero by 2050 plan is to use carbon capture and storage to help get emissions down from burning coal and gas. But is it a realistic option?

node.title: The Politics of a Sleeveless Silhouette
node.description: Michelle Obama, Kyrsten Sinema and the right to bare arms.

node.title: Dozens of Republican-Led States File Lawsuits Against Biden's Big-Business Vaccine Mandate
node.description: Missouri is leading one such lawsuit, which states that the mandate is "unconstitutional, unlawful, and unwise."
